elements.content: Three novel cadmium(II) coordination polymers, [Cd2(4,4‘-bipy)(3,3‘-bpda)2] n (1), [Cd4(bpe)3(μ-H2O)2(3,3‘-bpda)4] n (2), and [Cd2(3,3‘-bpda)2] n (3), have been hydrothermally synthesized by 1,1‘-biphenyl-3,3‘-dicarboxylate (3,3‘-bpda) and Cd(NO3)2·4H2O with exo-bidentate pyridyl-containing ligands, 4,4‘-bipyridine (4,4‘-bipy), 1,2-bi(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpe), and 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane (dpp), respectively. X-ray crystal structural analyses reveal that the three polymers possess different novel structural motifs derived from different conformations of the 3,3‘-bpda ligand. In 1, 3,3‘-bpda in a trans conformation links paddle wheel dimeric cadmium-tetracarboxylate building units resulting in a two-dimensional layer, which is further bridged by 4,4‘-bipy generating a three-dimensional framework with a 3-fold interpenetrating structure. 3,3‘-bpda in 2 has a cis conformation and bridges among six-coordinated and seven-coordinated CdII centers forming a tetranuclear cadmium unit, which is further connected by bpe producing a two-dimensional layer. The larger cavities in a layer of 2 result in mutually perpendicular interpenetrating two-dimensional layers. Complex 3 is an unprecedented three-dimensional polymer consisting of double chains formed from two different trans bridging 3,3‘-bpda and five-coordinated cadmium(II) centers.

elements.content: Three novel cadmium(II) coordination polymers based on different conformations of the ligands, [Cd2(4,4‘-bipy)(3,3‘-bpda)2] n (1), [Cd4(bpe)3(μ-H2O)2(3,3‘-bpda)4] n (2), and [Cd2(3,3‘-bpda)2] n (3), have been hydrothermally synthesized by 1,1‘-biphenyl-3,3‘-dicarboxylate (3,3‘-bpda), Cd(NO3)2·4H2O with rigid 4,4‘-bipyridine (4,4‘-bipy), flexible 1,2-bi(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpe), and 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane, respectively. 3,3‘-bpda in 1 and 3 adopts a transoid conformation; however, 3,3‘-bpda and bpe in 2 adopt cisoid and anti conformations, respectively.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of highly organized metal−organic frameworks have achieved considerable progress in supramolecular chemistry and material chemistry. The increasing interest in this field is justified not only by their potential application as functional materials but also by intriguing structural diversities of the architectures. By closely controlling the properties of the ligands, such as shape, functionality, flexibility, conformation, and symmetry, frameworks with fantastic structures and desirable properties can be created. Thus, the prospect of tuning the properties of metal−organic frameworks through a systematic change of the organic ligands provides an impetus to further research of metal−organic supramolecular architectures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of highly organized metal-organic frameworks have achieved considerable progress in supramolecular chemistry and material chemistry. The increasing interest in this field is justified not only by their potential application as functional materials but also by intriguing structural diversities of the architectures. By closely controlling the properties of the ligands, such as shape, functionality, flexibility, conformation, and symmetry, frameworks with fantastic structures and desirable properties can be created. Thus, the prospect of tuning the properties of metal-organic frameworks through a systematic change of the organic ligands provides an impetus to further research of metal-organic supramolecular architectures.

elements.content: Multidentate N- or O-donor ligands have been extensively employed in the construction of extended structures. For example, as an excellent candidate for rigid rodlike organic building units, exo-bidentate 4,4‘-bipyridine (4,4‘-bpy) has been relatively well-known and shows many interesting supramolecular architectures. Flexible ligands, such as 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpe) and its analogues, which can adopt the gauche and anti conformations, may induce supramolecular isomerism in their coordination. Dicarboxylate ligands can bridge two or more different metal centers and produce neutral architectures. Hence, metal−organic coordination polymers constructed by mixed ligands of pyridyl groups and carboxylate groups not only incorporate interesting properties of different functional group15 but also are more adjustive through changing one of the above two organic ligands. For instance, using dipyridyl ligands as pillars between the neutral layers of dicarboxylate and metal ions, a few three-dimensional layer−pillar complexes have been constructed. However, because of the difficult prediction of either the composition or the structure of the reaction product, the architectures of coordination polymers from mixed ligands and metal ions are still a long-term challenge to chemists, especially those from flexible bridging ligands because of their flexibility and conformational freedom in assembly process. Hence, a great deal of work is required to extend the knowledge of relevant structural types and establish proper synthetic strategies leading to desirable architectures and useful properties.

elements.content: Linear symmetrical biphenyl-4,4‘-dicarboxylate (4,4‘-bpda) has been well-documented in the construction of coordination polymers with larger channels and cavities. Very recently, we21 and others22 have obtained a series of macrocyclic and helical structures from 1,1‘-biphenyl-2,2‘-dicarboxylate (2,2‘-bpda) through making use of the distortion of the diphenyl connector about the central bond. However, efforts on 1,1‘-biphenyl-3,3‘-dicarboxylate (3,3‘-bpda) are still rare. To investigate the effects of rigid and flexible exo-bidentate pyridyl-containing ligands on conformations of 3,3‘-bpda as well as the assembly process of 3,3‘-bpda and metal ions, the hydrothermal reactions of 3,3‘-bpda with CdII and dipyridyl ligands were carried out and a series of coordination polymers were obtained. Herein, we report the syntheses and characterizations of three novel cadmium(II) compounds exhibiting different topologies:  [Cd2(4,4‘-bipy)(3,3‘-bpda)2] n (1), [Cd4(bpe)3(μ-H2O)2(3,3‘-bpda)4] n (2), and [Cd2(3,3‘-bpda)2] n (3).

elements.content: 1,1‘-Biphenyl-3,3‘-dicarboxylic acid was synthesized according to literature methods using 3-aminobenzoic acid as a starting material. 4,4‘-bpy, 1,2-bi(4-pyridyl)ethane, 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane (dpp), and 3-aminobenzoic acid were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification; all of the other reagents were commercially available and used as purchased. The IR spectra as a KBr disk were recorded on a Magna 750 FT-IR spectrophotometer. C, H, and N elemental analyses were determined on an Elementary Vario ELIII elemental analyzer. Thermal analyses were performed on a Thermal Analyst 2100 TA Instrument and SDT 2960 Simultaneous TGA-DTA Instrument.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

1,1‘-Biphenyl-3,3‘-dicarboxylic acid was synthesized according to literature methods using 3-aminobenzoic acid as a starting material. 4,4‘-bpy, 1,2-bi(4-pyridyl)ethane, 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane (dpp), and 3-aminobenzoic acid were  purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification; all of the other reagents were commercially available and used as purchased. The IR spectra as a KBr disk were recorded on a Magna 750 FT-IR spectrophotometer. C, H, and N elemental analyses were determined on an Elementary Vario ELIII elemental analyzer. Thermal analyses were performed on a Thermal Analyst 2100 TA Instrument and SDT 2960 Simultaneous TGA-DTA Instrument.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Cd 2 (4,4‘-bipy)(3,3‘-bpda) 2 ] n (1). A mixture of 3,3‘-H2bpda (0.12 g, 0.5 mmol), 4,4‘-bipy (0.08 g, 0.5 mmol), Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.15 g, 0.5 mmol), and NaOH (0.03 g, 0.75 mmol) with a molar ratio of about 2:2:2:3 in H2O (15.0 mL) was placed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 160 °C for 72 h. Then, the reaction system was cooled to room temperature during 24 h to give rise to colorless crystals of 1, which were collected by filtration. The colorless crystals obtained were washed with water and dried in air. Yield:  0.12 g (55% based on 3,3‘-H2bpda). Elementary analysis calcd for C19H12CdNO4 (430.70):  C, 52.98; H, 2.79; N, 3.25%; found:  C, 52.91; H, 2.82; N, 3.21%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3440 (vw, br), 3061 (vw), 1921 (vw), 1612 (s), 1564 (s), 1506 (w), 1487 (w), 1433 (m), 1408 (m), 1385 (s), 1303 (vw), 1263 (w), 1230 (w), 1140 (vw), 1080 (vw), 1074 (vw), 1022 (m), 910 (vw), 837 (w), 822 (w), 764 (s), 700 (m), 688 (m), 667 (vw), 619 (vw), 552 (vw), 530 (vw), 494 (w), 424 (w).

elements.content: X-ray Crystallographic Study. Intensity data for 1−3 were measured on a Siemens Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. All empirical absorption corrections were applied by using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods25 and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXL-97 program package. The positions of the H-atoms were generated geometrically (C−H bond fixed at 0.96 Å), assigned isotropic thermal parameters, and allowed to ride on their parent carbon atoms before the final cycle of refinement. Crystal data and a structure determination summary for 1−3 are listed in Table . The selected bond lengths and angles for 1−3 are listed in Table .

Syntheses and Characterization. The hydrothermal reactions of 3,3‘-bpda and Cd(NO3)2·4H2O with the pyridyl-containing exo-bidentate ligands (4,4‘-bipy, bpe, and dpp) at 160 °C have afforded colorless crystals of complexes 1−3, respectively. It is noteworthy that dpp was not involved in the coordination in 3. However, without dpp, the directed reaction of 3,3‘-bpda and Cd(NO3)2·4H2O under the same conditions produced uncharacterized precipitate insoluble in any common solvents, which suggests that dpp plays an important template role in the formation of 3.
elements.clean_text:
Result and Discussions

 Syntheses and Characterization. The hydrothermal reactions of 3,3‘-bpda and Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O with the pyridyl-containing exo-bidentate ligands (4,4‘-bipy, bpe, and dpp) at 160 °C have afforded colorless crystals of complexes 1-3, respectively. It is noteworthy that dpp was not involved in the coordination in 3. However, without dpp, the directed reaction of 3,3‘-bpda and Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O under the same conditions produced uncharacterized precipitate insoluble in any common solvents, which suggests that dpp plays an important template role in the formation of 3.

elements.content: The IR spectrum of complex 1 shows typical antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands of carboxylate groups at 1562 and 1385 cm-1, respectively. The separation (Δ) between νasym (CO2) and νsym(CO2) is 177 cm-1, indicating the presence of bis-bidentate bridging coordination modes in 3,3‘-bpda. For complex 2, the characteristic bands of the dicarboxylate groups are shown at 1593 and 1568 cm-1 for antisymmetric stretching and 1406 and 1385 cm-1 for symmetric stretching with the Δ values at 187 and 183 cm-1, respectively. Complex 3 shows the characteristic bands of dicarboxylate groups at 1595 cm-1 for antisymmetric stretching and 1410 and 1381 cm-1 for symmetric stretching, respectively. Their Δ values are at 185 and 214 cm-1, respectively. The respective Δ values in 2 and 3 reflect that the carboxylate groups of 3,3‘-bpda function in two different coordination fashions, which are consistent with the crystal structures in 2 and 3.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on polycrystalline samples in a nitrogen atmosphere. In complexes 1 and 2, there was no chemical decomposition up to 400 °C; the significant weight losses occur between 420 and 490 °C for 1 and between 410 and 530 °C for 2. However, the weight loss in complex 3 has been found in the range from 380 to 550 °C. Considering the formation of a stoichiometric amount of CdCO3, the residues of 41.13% (above 490 °C) for 1, 35.27% (above 530 °C) for 2, and 48.11% (above 550 °C) for 3 are in accordance with the expected values (40.03% for 1, 34.48% for 2, and 48.90% for 3, respectively).

elements.content: Structural Description. [Cd 2 (4,4‘-bipy)(3,3‘-bpda) 2 ] n (1). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 is a 3-fold interpenetrating three-dimensional coordination network consisting of dicadmium−tetracarboxylate units bridged by 3,3‘-bpda and 4,4‘-bipy. As shown in Figure a, each dinuclear unit has a crystallographic inversion center at the center of the Cd−CdA cores. The two CdII centers are bridged equivalently by four carboxylate groups from different 3,3‘-bpda ligands in a syn−syn bidentate mode forming a paddle wheel secondary building unit (SBU). Each CdII center is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from four different 3,3‘-bpda and a nitrogen atom of 4,4‘-bipy, in which five coordination atoms (CdO4N) occupy the vertexes of the perfect square pyramidal due to the symmetry of the dinuclear unit with a τ value of zero. The four carboxylate oxygen atoms comprise the equatorial plane with the average Cd−O bond distance being 2.219(6) Å, and the axial position is occupied by a pyridyl nitrogen atom with a Cd−N bond distance of 2.249(6) Å, which is similar to those found in related Cd−4,4‘-bipy coordination polymers [2.325(3)−2.344(3) Å]. The deviation of the CdII center from the O4 equatorial mean plane of the square pyramidal toward the apical nitrogen atom is 0.409 Å. The Cd···Cd distance in the SBU is 3.050(1) Å, which is significantly shorter than those in reported discrete dimeric cadmium−tetracarboxylate complexes (3.278−3.452 Å), but is slightly longer than the sum of the van der Waals radii of CdII of 3.04 Å, suggesting that there is no significant CdII−CdII interaction in the SBU. 3,3‘-Bpda adopts a trans conformation and serves as a bis-bidentate bridging ligand (Scheme a), the carboxylate groups are slightly twisted with respect to correspondingly linking phenyl rings with the dihedral angles 2.6 and 11.4°, and two phenyl rings about the central bond have a drastic twisting with a dihedral angle 145.2°, which is larger than those observed in metal−organic complexes derived from 2,2‘-bpda. The combination of these twistings results in 3,3‘-bpda linking the cadmium−tetracarboxylate SBU into a two-dimensional [Cd(3,3‘-bpda)] n layer (Figure b). The exo-bidentate 4,4‘-bipy bridges two adjacent layers to afford a three-dimensional open framework (Figure c). Two pyridyl rings in 4,4‘-bipy are coplanar; hence, 4,4‘-bipy may be regarded as a pillar of the [Cd(3,3‘-bpda)] n layer through trans coordinating to the SBUs of different layers along the diagonal direction of the a- and c-axes. 4,4‘-Bipy acting as a pillar has also been found in other complexes. The separations of Cd···Cd across the 3,3‘-bpda and 4,4‘-bipy are 13.80 and 11.563 Å, respectively. However, because of the absence of larger guest molecules to fill the larger void space in the three-dimensional network during the assembly process, the potential voids in 1, instead of forming an open, microporous structure, are filled via mutual interpenetration of three identical three-dimensional frameworks, which generates a 3-fold interpenetrating architecture (Figure d).

elements.content: It should be emphasized that because of the orientation of the carboxylate coordination sites and flexibility of 3,3‘-bpda, the quadrate rings in the two-dimensional [Cd(3,3‘-bpda)] n layer are highly distorted and arranged in a [ABAB···] alternation, which results in irregularity of the cuboidal [Cd16(3,3‘-bpda)8(4,4‘-bipy)4] n units in 1. However, when 4,4‘-bpy serves as a pillar between layers of terephthalate (tp) and CdII, a 2-fold interpenetrating three-dimensional structure is constructed, in which the cuboidal [Cd16(tp)8(4,4‘-bipy)4] n building units are more regular because of the linearity and rigidity of the bridging ligands. Hence, the construction of 1 not only results from the nonlinearity of coordination sites and greater lengths of the ligands but also from the higher flexibility of 3,3‘-bpda, which allows it to bend freely inside the cavities.

elements.content: [Cd 4 (bpe) 3 ( μ -H 2 O) 2 (3,3‘-bpda) 4 ] n (2). Complex 2 is made up of mutually perpendicular interpenetrating two-dimensional layers formed through bpe bridging [Cd4(3,3‘-bpda)4] building units. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetry unit consists of two independent CdII centers, two 3,3‘-bpda ligands, one bridging water molecule, and one and a half bpe molecules. The Cd(1) adopts a distorted octahedral geometry in a CdNO5 fashion, in which four carboxylate oxygen atoms from different 3,3‘-bpda comprise the equatorial plane, and one pyridyl nitrogen atom of bpe and one bridging water molecule occupy the axial positions [N(1)−Cd(1)−O(w) 163.34(13)°]. The bond angles between the cis ligands and the Cd(1) center range from 70.27(11) to 98.13(13)°. However, Cd(2) is in a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry with two asymmetrically chelating carboxylate groups from different 3,3‘-bpdas and one pyridyl nitrogen atom from bpe occupying the equatorial basal plane and one bridging water molecule and one pyridyl nitrogen atom from the other bpe at the apical sites [N(3)−Cd(2)−O(w) 169.86(12)°]. The Cd(1) and Cd(2) are displaced by about 0.1776 and 0.2496 Å from the equatorial planes toward the axial donor atoms, respectively. The Cd−N and Cd−O bond distances are all within the normal range. The bond angle of Cd(1)−O(w)−Cd(2) is 88.34(11)°. Interestingly, all 3,3‘-bpda ligands adopt a cis conformation. Two carboxylate groups of 3,3‘-bpda have two different coordination modes (Scheme b). In the first mode, one oxygen atom of the carboxylate group [O(11) and O(31)] coordinates to Cd(1) in a monodentate fashion, and the other oxygen atom forms a strong hydrogen bond with a coordination water molecule [O(w)−H···O(12) = 2.633; O(w)-H···O(32) = 2.583 Å]; the carboxlate group is not coplanar with corresponding linking phenyl rings with the dihedral angles 4.5 and 9.7°. In the second mode, it bridges between Cd(1) and Cd(2) through chelating with Cd(2) and coordinating to Cd(1) in a chelating/bridging fashion. The distortion angles of 4.6 and 16.7° between the carboxylate group and the corresponding linking phenyl ring are slightly different from the former. The bond angles of Cd(1)−O(22A)−Cd(2) and Cd(1)−O(44A)−Cd(2) are 93.35(11) and 93.91(12)°, respectively. The distance of Cd(1)···Cd(2) is 3.420 Å, which is longer than that in the SBU of complex 1. Four 3,3‘-bpdas bridge both Cd(1) and Cd(2) forming an unprecedented tetranuclear cadmium building unit with a crystallographic inversion center at the center of the Cd(1)−Cd(1) cores. The separations of Cd(1)···Cd(1) and Cd(2)···Cd(2) in the tetramer is 5.793 and 12.626 Å, respectively. The latter value is very close to the sum of distances in Cd(1)···Cd(1A) and two Cd(1)···Cd(2), suggesting that the four CdII atoms are linear. The structural motif is not only different from that in 1 but also different from other reported metal(II)−dicarboxylate complexes composed of dinuclear metal centers. The dihedral angles between two phenyl rings of two independent 3,3‘-bpda are 31.0 and 43.4°, respectively, suggesting a cis conformation and being responsible for its formation. There are two kinds of bpe, and both adopt a distorted anti conformation. One, bridging between six-coordinated and seven-coordinated CdII centers, links the tetranuclear cadmium building units into a one-dimensional chain as shown in Figure S2b of the Supporting Information. Two pyridyl rings in the bpe are approximately perpendicular to each other with the dihedral angle between them being 91.3°. Two pyridyl rings in the other bpe are coplanar, and it bridges seven-coordinated CdII centers and further connects the one-dimensional chain generating a two-dimensional network containing ladder-like chains. These two kinds of bpe form side pieces and the inner rung of the ladder with Cd···Cd separation across bpe being 13.481 and 13.871 Å, respectively. Six-coordinated and seven-coordinated CdII centers bridged by water molecules occupy the apical position of the ladder. Although many ladder motifs have been reported, the ladder framework in 2 is still unprecedented. Because of the absence of solvent or guest molecules in the ladder framework, the larger cavities have been effectively filled via mutually perpendicular interpenetration of the symmetry equivalent layers with the same structure and composition in the bc plane.

elements.content: [Cd 2 (3,3‘-bpda) 2 ] n (3). The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 3 is a three-dimensional polymer consisting of carboxylate-bridged edge-sharing Cd−O−Cd double chains. As shown in Figure a, CdII is in a trigonal-bipyramidal geometry and is coordinated by five carboxylate atoms from different 3,3‘-bpda ligands. The Cd−O bond distances are in the range from 2.158(3) to 2.280(4) Å, which are typical values for Cd−Ocoo bond distances. There are two types of coordination modes for the bridging 3,3‘-bpda ligands in a trans conformation:  one adopts a bis-bidentate mode (Scheme a), in which two phenyl rings are coplanar, showing a perfect trans conformation; the other acts as a bis-tridentate bridging ligand (Scheme c) with the dihedral angle between two phenyl rings being 140.2°. The dihedral angles between carboxylate groups and correspondingly linking phenyl rings for bis-bidentate and bis-tridentate 3,3‘-bpda are 4.1 and 21.1°, respectively, in which a larger distortion in bis-tridentate 3,3‘-bpda can be ascribed to the role of its one carboxylate oxygen atom bridging two CdII centers. As shown in Figure b, each bis-tridentate 3,3‘-bpda bridges six CdII forming a two-dimensional layer structure. μ-O (O22) connects CdII into an edge-sharing Cd−O−Cd chain with the adjacent Cd···Cd separation being 3.786 Å; the other carboxylate oxygen atom (O21) coordinates to the adjacent chain to form double edge-sharing Cd−O−Cd chains; the closest Cd···Cd separations between chains is 4.304 Å. Bis-bidentate bpda further extends the two-dimensional layer into a three-dimensional architecture through bridging two adjacent double chains. To the best our knowledge, this is the first three-dimensional inorganic−organic hybrid complex containing the carboxylate-bridged edge-sharing Cd−O−Cd double chains.

elements.content: Three novel cadmium(II) coordination polymers with different structural motifs based on mixed ligands of 3,3‘-bpda and dipyridyl ligands (rigid 4,4-bipy, flexible bpe, and dpp) have been hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. In 1 and 3, 3,3‘-bpda behaves in a trans conformation when coordinating to CdII centers; however, in 2, flexible 3,3‘-bpda and bpe bridge CdII in cis and anti conformations, respectively. More flexible dpp in 3 is not involved in coordination and serves as a template in the course of assembly of 3,3‘-bpda and CdII. Three-fold interpenetration of three-dimensional coordination networks in 1 and mutually perpendicular interpenetration of two-dimensional layers in 2 result in highly stable crystal structures. In summary, this research demonstrates that the assembly of 3,3‘-bpda and dipyridyl ligands with different connector and metal ions not only can afford novel supramolecular architectures owning different structures and functions but also can induce 3,3‘-bpda to adopt different conformations in the presence of dipyridyl ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Three novel cadmium(II) coordination polymers with different structural motifs based on mixed ligands of 3,3‘-bpda and dipyridyl ligands (rigid 4,4-bipy, flexible bpe, and dpp) have been hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. In 1 and 3, 3,3‘-bpda behaves in a trans conformation when coordinating to CdII centers; however, in 2, flexible 3,3‘-bpda and bpe bridge CdII in cis and anti conformations, respectively. More flexible dpp in 3 is not involved in coordination and serves as a template in the course of assembly of 3,3‘-bpda and CdII. Three-fold interpenetration of three-dimensional coordination networks in 1 and mutually perpendicular interpenetration of two-dimensional layers in 2 result in highly stable crystal structures. In summary, this research demonstrates that the assembly of 3,3‘-bpda and dipyridyl ligands with different connector and metal ions not only can afford novel supramolecular architectures owning different structures and functions but also can induce 3,3‘-bpda to adopt different conformations in the presence of dipyridyl ligands.

Synthesis of [Cd 2 (4,4‘-bipy)(3,3‘-bpda) 2 ] n (1). A mixture of 3,3‘-H2bpda (0.12 g, 0.5 mmol), 4,4‘-bipy (0.08 g, 0.5 mmol), Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.15 g, 0.5 mmol), and NaOH (0.03 g, 0.75 mmol) with a molar ratio of about 2:2:2:3 in H2O (15.0 mL) was placed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 160 °C for 72 h. Then, the reaction system was cooled to room temperature during 24 h to give rise to colorless crystals of 1, which were collected by filtration. The colorless crystals obtained were washed with water and dried in air. Yield:  0.12 g (55% based on 3,3‘-H2bpda). Elementary analysis calcd for C19H12CdNO4 (430.70):  C, 52.98; H, 2.79; N, 3.25%; found:  C, 52.91; H, 2.82; N, 3.21%. cln_elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on polycrystalline samples in a nitrogen atmosphere. In complexes 1 and 2, there was no chemical decomposition up to 400 °C; the significant weight losses occur between 420 and 490 °C for 1 and between 410 and 530 °C for 2. However, the weight loss in complex 3 has been found in the range from 380 to 550 °C. Considering the formation of a stoichiometric amount of CdCO3, the residues of 41.13% (above 490 °C) for 1, 35.27% (above 530 °C) for 2, and 48.11% (above 550 °C) for 3 are in accordance with the expected values (40.03% for 1, 34.48% for 2, and 48.90% for 3, respectively).
